title: What's a good way to teach a six year old how to play the piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: The way me and my siblings first learned from our parents were "by color".(Though, I guess we were all younger than six) The first songs we learned to play were music we listen to or sang, like "twinkle, twinkle little start", "itsy-bitsy spider" and so on...- so what our parents did, was giving each (white) key on the C-gradation in the middle of the piano a color (by putting a small colored sticker on the key)Then, in our song book, they added the same color to the corresponding note. (In some cases - if there were no book with the particular song - they took a blank sheet, wrote the lyrics of the song, and the corresponding colors for the melody.) This way, we learned pretty fast that:Pink = C, Green=D, Red = E, Yellow = F, Blue=G, Brown=A, Purple = B, Light blue =  C- and in the same way, we also learned the corresponding notes for each color....so after a while, we could also play songs that was not color coded, since we learned the notes for each key. We never had a private piano teacher - though we all have been playing at public "music school". (In Sweden, it's free for children to learn an instrument at school, when you are between 9 and 18. So in a way you have a private teacher, since you have a lesson once a week)But our parents are musical and plays plays the piano and guitar - so, we got a lot from them. Most important though: Make it fun to play!

You have lots of good responses here. Having taught (and still teach) MANY children in that age range, the idea of several diverse activities as opposed to the traditional notation-based hour-long private piano lesson is usually better received by young students. Sitting for more than twenty minutes at a piano is usually torturous for young children who by nature need to move and play.   I taught private piano through traditional, classical-based notation methods for many  years, but when I discovered MusikGarten's curriculum, I found it to be highly effective for younger children especially (5-8 years of age ).  MusikGarten's curriculum uses a mixture of games, theory and aural training, drumming, movement, listening assignments and finally, keyboarding to teach piano . From my personal experience, it works really well.  Students I've taught via MusikGarten curriculum stayed focused longer, were engaged, and because of the diversity of approaches, well-prepared for developing piano-playing skills.  I highly recommend searching for a local MusikGarten instructor.  Of course, the curriculum itself is pretty useless if the teacher does not connect with the student.  That is a subjective, personal issue, so keep teacher shopping until you find the right fit.  But don't be hesitant to express any concerns to the teacher, who may be able to accomodate a positive, workable change once enlightened to any particular issues.
